meanings.definition: Capable of being held or maintained for a period of time.
meanings.sent1: The old house was tenurable despite its age.
meanings.sent2: The contract was tenurable for five years.
meanings.sent3: The idea of a tenurable friendship made them smile.
meanings.sent4: Her memories were tenurable, like precious jewels in her mind.
meanings.sent5: The tenurable nature of the tradition made it a cherished custom.

meanings.definition: Able to be defended or justified.
meanings.sent1: His argument was tenurable in the court of law.
meanings.sent2: The decision was tenurable based on the evidence presented.
meanings.sent3: She found a tenurable excuse for being late.
meanings.sent4: The belief in magic was not tenurable in the face of science.
meanings.sent5: The plan was tenurable, ensuring success in the long run.

meanings.sent1: After years of service, he became tenurable for a permanent position.
meanings.sent2: The professor was finally tenurable after meeting all the requirements.
meanings.sent3: She felt proud to be tenurable in her dream job.
meanings.sent4: The employee proved to be tenurable through dedication and hard work.
meanings.sent5: Being tenurable brought a sense of security to his career.
